document.masterDocTitle: Coralliophilinae (Neogastropoda: Muricidae) from the southwest Pacific

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Coralliophilinae (Neogastropoda: Muricidae) from the southwest Pacific
Mémoires du Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle

subSubSection.paragraph:
Fusus neritoideus Lamarck, 1816
: pl. 435, figs 2a, b.

TYPE MATERIAL. —
Murex neritoideus Gmelin
, Chemnitz’s (1788) figured specimen. The originally figured specimen has not been found either in ZMUC (Ole Tendal, pers. comm.) or in ZIN ( Martynov 2002 ). —
Pyrula neritoidea Lamarck, 1822
is in my opinion the same as
Fusus neritoideus Lamarck, 1816
, and both are in turn new combinations for
Murex neritoideus Gmelin, 1791
. Thus, the 2 specimens of
Pyrula neritoidea
in MHNG ( MHNG 1098/70/1 and /2), out of the 5 originally present (according to handwritten notes by Lamarck’s daughter, Rosalie: Y. Finet, pers. comm.) are not deemed to have type status. The 2 specimens are compatible with the original size of “18 lignes” (Lamarck 1816: 435), i.e. about 4 cm ( MHNG 1098/70/1, 39.4 mm (Fig. 207), possibly the one figured by Kiener; MHNG 1098/70/2, 37.2 mm, actually a specimen of
C. radula Adams
). The locality indicated on the subsequent label (no original label of Lamarck is preserved) reads “Océanie”.

TYPE LOCALITY. —
P. violacea Kiener
: Nicobar Islands , “an den Stranden der Nicobarischen Enlande” (Chemnitz 1788: 280).

MATERIAL EXAMINED. —
Coral Sea .
CORAIL 2: stn CP 90, la Thiem , 20°45.2’S , 165°08’E ,
9-11 m
, 2 dd; stn 1271, Secteur Plateau des Chesterfield , 19°03’S , 158°56’E ,
44-48 m
, 2 dd; stn de Touho , 20°52.7’S , 165°19.5’E ,
5-25 m
, 1 dd
.

Récif Mangalia , 20°41’S , 165°07’E ,
27 m
, 1 dd
. —
EXPÉDITION Additional material: many lots (lv and dd) from Red Sea , So- MONTROUZIER: stn 1254,
Secteur de Touho
, 20°46.1’S , cotra Is., Madagascar , Celebes ( Indonesia ), Philippines , Cook 165°14.6’E ,
7 m
, 11 dd; stn 1268,
Secteur de Touho
, parages de Islands , in MO
.

DISTRIBUTION. — The entire Indo-Pacific. From the Red Sea, the western Indian Ocean, eastern Arabia “among corals” (
Bosch et al . 1995
) through the tropical Indian Ocean. Pacific Ocean, from Izu Islands southward to tropical Indo-Pacific, subtidal associated with
Porites
(Tsuchiya 2000; as
C. neritoides
[ sic ]), “firmly attached to the underside of coral rocks” ( Cernohorsky 1972 ). The tropical eastern Pacific, Panamic province to Ecuador (Keen 1971). From the Coral Sea, New Caledonia and Loyalty Islands , live in 4-25 m , empty shells down to
53 m .

REMARKS. —
Coraliophilla violacea
is one of the best studied coralliophiline species (e.g. Chen & Soong 2002; Chen, Yang & Soong 1998 ; Lin & Liu 1995; Soong & Cheng 1991). It is almost invariably associated with
Porites
scleractinians. Protoconch of 3.2 conical whorls, 590 Μm high, 600 Μm wide at the base. Protoconch-I of about 1 whorl, sculptured with pustules over the entire surface. Protoconch-II of about 2.2 whorls, with 2 spiral keels (the abapical starting on the second protoconch whorl, the adapical starting on the third), sculptured by a series of subsutural prosocline threads and a series of oblong tubercles over each keel; a diffuse granulation is present in the interspaces.

The nomenclatural history of this species was summarized clearly by Cernohorsky (1985) .
Murex neritoideus Gmelin, 1791
is not valid, being a junior primary homonym of
Murex neritoideus Linné, 1767
(a thaidine species, possibly a synonym of
Thais nodosa ( Linné, 1758 )
[
Nerita
]).
Fusus neritoideus Lamarck, 1816
is evidently a new combination for
Murex neritoideus Gmelin. Lamarck (1822: 146)
clearly referred
Pyrula neritoidea
to Gmelin’s taxon; this is an indication that his 1816
Fusus neritoideus
was simply a re-assignment of Gmelin’s
Murex
to the genus
Fusus
(if
Fusus neritoideus Lamarck, 1816
was an independent introduction of a new species, then it would be invalid, as a secondary homonym of
Murex neritoideus Gmelin
). Finally, Kiener (1836), evidently recognising “Lamarck’s homonymous usage of
neritoideus
... proposed the replacement name
Purpura violacea ” ( Cernohorsky 1985: 53 )
. Under these circumstances, the only remaining problem concerns the type locality designation. Rehder (1980) designated “ New Caledonia ” as type locality of
P. violacea Kiener
(who possibly figured one of Lamarck’s shells, from “Océanie”). Cernohorsky (1985: 53) designated Port Dorey as type locality, “being the centre of the species distributional range”. I agree that
Purpura violacea Kiener
is to be considered as a replacement name, and therefore its name-bearing type is the same as
F. neritoideus Lamarck
and
M. neritoideus Gmelin
, i.e., Chemnitz’s figured shell (ICZN 1999: Article 72.7); the same holds for the type locality, which is permanently linked to the name-bearing type (s) (ICZN 1999: Article 76), from the Nicobar Islands . Chemnitz’s figured shell might yet be discovered in St. Petersburg, where the Chemnitz collection requires detailed investigation.
